name: Adding fractions with denominators of 10 and 100

skills.name: Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers
Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other

explanations.A: To find equivalent fractions we multiply the numerator and denominator by the same value. What have we multiplied 10 by? Do the same to the 3...
explanations.B: 3/10 does equal 0.3 but the question is asking what is 3/10 as a fraction out of 100?
explanations.C: To find equivalent fractions we multiply the numerator and denominator by the same value. Here we have multiplied the 10 by 10 to get 100 so we need to do the same with the 3 and 3 x 10 = 30 so 3/10 = 30/100
explanations.D: I think because 10 + 90 = 100 you have added 90 to the 3 but what we have actually done to get 100 is 10 x 10 so you need to do 3 x 10...

explanations.A: To find equivalent fractions we multiply the numerator and denominator by the same value. Here we have multiplied the 10 by 10 to get 100 so we need to do the same with the 4 and 4 x 10 = 40 so 4/10 = 40/100
explanations.B: To find equivalent fractions we multiply the numerator and denominator by the same value. What have we multiplied 10 by? Do the same to the 4...
explanations.C: 4/10 does equal 0.4 but the question is asking what is 4/10 as a fraction out of 100?
explanations.D: I think because 10 + 90 = 100 you have added 90 to the 4 but what we have actually done to get 100 is 10 x 10 so you need to do 4 x 10...

explanations.A: To find equivalent fractions we multiply the numerator and denominator by the same value. Here we have multiplied the 10 by 10 to get 100 so we need to do the same with the 7 and 7 x 10 = 70 so 7/10 = 70/100
explanations.B: 7/10 does equal 0.7 as a decimal but the question is asking what is 7/10 as a fraction out of 100?
explanations.C: To find equivalent fractions we multiply the numerator and denominator by the same value. What have we multiplied 10 by? Do the same to the 7...
explanations.D: I think because 10 + 90 = 100 you have added 90 to the 7 but what we have actually done to get 100 is 10 x 10 so you need to do 7 x 10...

explanations.A: 6/10 does equal 0.6 as a decimal but the question is asking what is 6/10 as a fraction out of 100?
explanations.B: I think because 10 + 90 = 100 you have added 90 to the 6 but what we have actually done to get 100 is 10 x 10 so you need to do 6 x 10...
explanations.C: To find equivalent fractions we multiply the numerator and denominator by the same value. What have we multiplied 10 by? Do the same to the 6...
explanations.D: To find equivalent fractions we multiply the numerator and denominator by the same value. Here we have multiplied the 10 by 10 to get 100 so we need to do the same with the 6 and 6 x 10 = 60 so 6/10 = 60/100

explanations.A: Before you can add the numerators you need to make both the fractions out of 100...
explanations.B: When adding fractions, you need a common denominator: 3/10 = 30/100. Now we can do 30/100 + 7/100 = 37/100
explanations.C: This would be the correct answer if the denominator was 10 but it's 100...
explanations.D: This is the correct answer as a decimal but the question wants the answer as a fraction out of 100...

explanations.A: When adding fractions, you need a common denominator: 2/5 = 20/50. Now we can do 20/50 + 9/50 = 29/50
explanations.B: This would be the correct answer if the denominator was 5 but it's 50...
explanations.C: Before you can add the numerators you need to make both the fractions out of 50...
explanations.D: This is the correct answer as a decimal but the question wants the answer as a fraction out of 50...

explanations.A: Remember when adding fractions, you first need to find a common denominator and then you only add the numerators...
explanations.B: This would be the numerator but the question wants the final answer...
explanations.C: When adding fractions, you need a common denominator: 7/10 = 70/100. Now we can do 70/100 + 3/100 = 73/100
explanations.D: This would be the correct answer if the denominator was 10 but it's 100...

explanations.A: This would be the correct answer if the denominator was 10 but it's 100...
explanations.B: When adding fractions, you need a common denominator: 2/10 = 20/100. Now we can do 20/100 + 43/100 = 63/100
explanations.C: Remember when adding fractions, you first need to find a common denominator and then you only add the numerators...
explanations.D: This would be the numerator but the question wants the final answer...

explanations.B: I think you have added the numerators and denominators but first you need to find a common denominator and then you only add the numerators!
explanations.C: Find a common denominator, add the numerators and then compare the values!
explanations.D: Each symbol means something different: < means the value on the right is greatest, = means the values are equal and > means the value on the left is greatest...

explanations.A: Find a common denominator, add the numerators and then compare the values!
explanations.B: I think you have added the numerators and denominators but first you need to find a common denominator and then you only add the numerators!
explanations.D: Each symbol means something different: < means the value on the right is greatest, = means the values are equal and > means the value on the left is greatest...
